title: Thoughts on AI progress
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-03, Reading time: 14 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fwww.dwarkesh.com%2Fp%2Fthoughts-on-ai-progress-dec-2025%3Futm_source=tldrai/1/0100019ae4942089-056b3ae6-4c19-4178-9a46-9bb0d0d00e42-000000/6XYmCW093kM3REYf07UTvX4djvVjvlPf7dQEaR0lRNg=434
summary: Thoughts on AI progress (Dec 2025) (14 minute read) The driver for further improvement will be continual learning. Solving continual learning will require incremental improvements, just like solving in-context learning. Labs will likely release something next year that they will call continual learning, but it will just be progress towards continual learning. Human-level continual learning may take another five to ten years of further progress.

summary: Decoding High-bandwidth Memory: A Practical Guide to GPU Memory for Fine-tuning AI (6 minute read) Full fine-tuning is memory-heavy and often impractical. title: Everyone in Seattle Hates AI
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-04, Reading time: 6 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fjonready.com%2Fblog%2Fposts%2Feveryone-in-seattle-hates-ai.html%3Futm_source=tldrnewsletter/1/0100019ae91ab895-b78bfd10-8959-443c-a741-23741d22e204-000000/bPtVyLRStMWYeKuqyJNWnR6e6_6ZUlDmNgpoQPB3Pzg=434
summary: Everyone in Seattle Hates AI (6 minute read) Tech workers in Seattle tend to react negatively when the topic of AI is brought up. This is due to several reasons, like layoffs due to AI, the proliferation of AI in software, and being forced to use AI tools whether they work or not. The result is that engineers are no longer trying because they think they can't, and companies aren't empowering them because they assume they shouldn't. Bad products are only reinforcing the belief that AI is doomed.

summary: My Favorite Principle (4 minute read) "Levo's Principle" states that an object's behavior should remain constant after construction to improve code clarity, reduce bugs, and simplify refactoring. title: Should CSS be Constraints?
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-04, Reading time: 10 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fpavpanchekha.com%2Fblog%2Fwhy-css-bad.html%3Futm_source=tldrdev/1/0100019ae943e5e6-8ee22876-7dbe-493c-87e0-0533a99a9978-000000/SlQlAoziyB1E4W373Xv642V9T01_5OOEKoyONWdUnAQ=434
summary: Should CSS be Constraints? (10 minute read) CSS layout rules are complex and hard to pick up just from examples. One commonly-proposed replacement for CSS is a constraint system. Rule-based systems can be complex and hard to predict, but it is almost impossible to create a layout that is not under- or over-determined. A better way to improve CSS would be to provide more intuitive rule systems with more predictable, less esoteric rules.

title: Touching the Elephant - TPUs

title: Defining Reinforcement Learning Down
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-04, Reading time: 4 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fwww.argmin.net%2Fp%2Fdefining-reinforcement-learning-down%3Futm_source=tldrai/1/0100019ae9d6d9a1-05f46ead-87a0-49b5-920c-df8a05d4db02-000000/aak_04oJLVrecLe3oamFoSK8V7sysj9FCic70PxgvaY=434
summary: Defining Reinforcement Learning Down (4 minute read) Reinforcement learning (aka post-training) is simpler than it sounds: generate responses, get scores, then retrain while emphasizing the high-scoring ones. If you already have code to pretrain a model, you can turn it into post-training code by adding a single line that weights updates by score.

title: How confessions can keep language models honest
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-04, Reading time: 10 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Flinks.tldrnewsletter.com%2FOB7Aqt/1/0100019ae9d6d9a1-05f46ead-87a0-49b5-920c-df8a05d4db02-000000/CoHoCvI3G3fvU0uXlQkXbZeoPPx1zI5ifRJLdxirIUc=434
summary: How confessions can keep language models honest (10 minute read) When models optimize for correctness, helpfulness, and safety all at once, they can learn shortcuts to “reward hack” while hiding misbehavior in plausible-looking outputs. OpenAI trained a version of GPT-5 to produce a separate "confession" judged only on honesty and found models will admit to reward hacking 90% of the time, even when they hide it in their primary response.

summary: Stacking Dependencies (26 minute read) Inspired by the XKCD comic about software dependency towers, this dev created a tool to visualize dependency graphs as physical towers. He encountered an NP-hard problem that required him to explore graph theory and various algorithms, ultimately combining a barycentric heuristic with PQ-tree pruning for fast layout generation. The resulting tool normalizes the dependency graph and then renders it as stackable towers with information about maintainers.

title: Building Deep Research: How we Achieved State of the Art
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-05, Reading time: 8 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fhuggingface.co%2Fblog%2FTavily%2Ftavily-deep-research%3Futm_source=tldrdev/1/0100019aee7ce3c5-54d34d99-2ac7-44c4-a917-617fee933856-000000/JHy0tqhOTXV0N9ccct6ryRfPDZul-3rfVQM2cYS_AhU=434
summary: Building Deep Research: How we Achieved State of the Art (8 minute read) Tavily rebuilt its research agent from scratch after overengineering the first version with assumptions that broke when new models arrived. Instead of passing all tool outputs through the agent loop like most systems do, it distilled outputs into compact reflections and only loaded raw sources for final generation. This cut token usage by 66% while hitting SOTA on benchmarks.

title: Becoming great at listening
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-05, Reading time: 3 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fshreyasdoshi.substack.com%2Fp%2Fbecoming-great-at-listening%3Futm_source=tldrfounders/1/0100019aeea001ce-6f02cf55-211a-4c98-87e8-d5943a045391-000000/4hH7wQ7Ub7laSeFlpuVXT5xiSxsolPFqWkAJWh_t3ck=434
summary: Becoming great at listening (3 minute read) Your job as a listener is to consume decades of someone else's experience in minutes. This is impossible if you are busy mentally scripting your reply. The secret to world-class communication is to treat listening and thinking as mutually exclusive states. Turn off your analysis engine completely while they speak. When they finish, ask for a "thinking pause." That awkward silence is the only way to truly synthesize reality before you act on it.

title: Tether in 2025: A Capital Analysis
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-05, Reading time: 15 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fdirtroads.substack.com%2Fp%2F67-tether-in-2025-a-capital-analysis%3Futm_source=tldrcrypto/1/0100019aeea04b68-add5b1a4-193c-4c74-801f-bbb2b7fbdaa3-000000/5Jrue5yPxAdqEGyFc9Us7ky8Th5kmThOf7Dj3j07zmE=434
summary: Tether in 2025: A Capital Analysis (15 minute read) Tether is like an unregulated bank rather than a simple money transmitter. Depending mostly on how harshly you treat BTC, Tether's total capital ratio ranges from ~10.9% (OK vs minimal regulatory standards) down to ~3.9% (bad vs market norms). Group-level profits and equity look big, but most sit outside the actual reserve entity and aren't legally committed to back USDT redemptions, so they can't be counted as true regulatory capital.

title: PeerDAS: How Fusaka Makes L2s Cheaper
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-05, Reading time: 2 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fthreadreaderapp.com%2Fthread%2F1986678949280391640.html%3Futm_source=tldrcrypto/1/0100019aeea04b68-add5b1a4-193c-4c74-801f-bbb2b7fbdaa3-000000/KvpEMhB7qjP1lc2cRHYtMQwKDOD32XG2tMh0TWuV820=434
summary: PeerDAS: How Fusaka Makes L2s Cheaper (2 minute read) Fusaka's main feature, PeerDAS, changes how Ethereum stores blob data. Instead of every node keeping full copies of each blob, nodes only store a small slice of every blob while still being able to verify that the full data exists. That means the network can safely handle many more blobs per block, which lowers data-availability costs for rollups. More blobs per block means cheaper L2 data and cheaper L2 transactions for users.

title: Frontier AI Models Demonstrate Human-Level Capability in Smart Contract Exploits
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-05, Reading time: 4 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fdecrypt.co%2F350575%2Fai-models-human-level-capability-smart-contract-exploits%3Futm_source=tldrinfosec/1/0100019aeed800f8-e7d24dd5-f51a-4c75-b5d4-1dd422a5ef94-000000/sgwHSGdJAPfiUAa4U1TKncZ0z2oB3xRthrZlSHeAq1A=434
summary: Frontier AI Models Demonstrate Human-Level Capability in Smart Contract Exploits (4 minute read) Anthropic evaluated ten frontier models on a dataset of 405 historical smart contract exploits and found that the agents produced working attacks against 207 of them, totaling $550M in simulated stolen funds. Anthropic measured the model's current capabilities by plotting each model's total exploit revenue against its release date. The models also discovered two previously undisclosed zero-days.

title: We Got Claude to Fine-Tune an Open Source LLM
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-05, Reading time: 15 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fhuggingface.co%2Fblog%2Fhf-skills-training%3Futm_source=tldrai/1/0100019aeef6a1be-c5707be7-2ccc-4e6f-9616-fe892eab8ed9-000000/7fM5lkEy7jXKCyLK9oIQkFQApXQpX_YOvIbFjhs6nzc=434
summary: We Got Claude to Fine-Tune an Open Source LLM (15 minute read) Hugging Face Skills gives Claude the ability to fine-tune language models. It can submit jobs to cloud GPUs, monitor progress, and push finished models to the Hugging Face Hub. This tutorial teaches readers how it works and how to use it. The tool allows users to train models from 0.5B to 70B parameters, convert them to GGUF for local deployment, and run multi-stage pipelines that combine different techniques.

title: Context Engineering for AI Agents
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-05, Reading time: 7 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fwww.philschmid.de%2Fcontext-engineering-part-2%3Futm_source=tldrai/1/0100019aeef6a1be-c5707be7-2ccc-4e6f-9616-fe892eab8ed9-000000/33ZQAplKDKo93LLw0wo1V4FyiF6sj3riivkMPyNykvA=434
summary: Context Engineering for AI Agents (7 minute read) The field of context engineering is moving fast. However, the biggest performance gains nowadays come from removing complexity. As models get stronger, we should be getting out of the model's way. Context engineering is about minding the minimal effective context required for the next step, not about adding more context.

title: Architecting efficient context-aware multi-agent framework for production

title: A Modern Guide to SQL JOINs
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-08, Reading time: 18 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fkb.databasedesignbook.com%2Fposts%2Fsql-joins%2F%3Futm_source=tldrdata/1/0100019afda5395a-c3bdafbc-7a92-4ae7-b877-cf8766adf713-000000/Vq-HqeMU6aczKZ8bWo1DOr4Fu7I01S3E3etCMv_-Byo=434
summary: A Modern Guide to SQL JOINs (18 minute read) LEFT JOIN with ID-only ON clauses forms the core foundation for SQL JOINs, preserving left-table rows and cleanly handling N:1 and 1:N relationships (with NULLs where needed). INNER JOIN is a filtered Cartesian product. Best practices include explicit aliases, N:1 join order for performance, nested-loop thinking, moving non-ID filters to WHERE, and avoiding Venn diagrams and non-equality ON conditions.

summary: Build multi-step applications and AI workflows with AWS Lambda durable functions (3 minute read) AWS Lambda durable functions let developers write sequential, long-running workflows with automatic checkpoints, retries, and year-long waits without paying for idle compute. Using an open source SDK, they simplify state management for complex processes like approvals while preserving the standard Lambda programming model.

title: Cloudflare outage on December 5, 2025
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-08, Reading time: 6 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fblog.cloudflare.com%2F5-december-2025-outage%2F%3Futm_source=tldrdevops/1/0100019afdeb0004-29db0d24-6ef5-486b-9d27-5dc19ce0de40-000000/rvmFs4rufKY66f-B88onk-wGhZylnaXRt4faPp-OxCU=434
summary: Cloudflare outage on December 5, 2025 (6 minute read) Cloudflare experienced a 25-minute network outage on December 5 that impacted approximately 28% of its HTTP traffic. It was caused by a configuration change designed to disable a WAF testing tool. This action inadvertently exposed a long-undetected bug in its FL1 proxy's rules module, leading to HTTP 500 errors. This marks the company's second major incident in weeks.

title: Estimates – a necessary evil?
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-08, Reading time: 11 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fthorsell.io%2F2025%2F12%2F07%2Festimates.html%3Futm_source=tldrdevops/1/0100019afdeb0004-29db0d24-6ef5-486b-9d27-5dc19ce0de40-000000/nrZrN2BmOOWGXiny_XJruIemkUzguDMHtDMG5TFMcQ0=434
summary: Estimates – a necessary evil? (11 minute read) Estimates are essential for product owners to prioritize and plan releases, but developers dislike them because they're inherently uncertain and often get misused as commitments or deadlines. The real problem isn't estimating itself — it's the unrealistic expectations and pressure created when tentative estimates are treated as promises.

comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-08, Reading time: 3 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fwww.sysdig.com%2Fblog%2Fdetecting-react2shell%3Futm_source=tldrdevops/1/0100019afdeb0004-29db0d24-6ef5-486b-9d27-5dc19ce0de40-000000/cIszWiEB6KSMxxaaWHeFIk0JNBamgrTKzI3tV8iHqLo=434
summary: Detecting React2Shell: The maximum-severity RCE Vulnerability affecting React Server Components and Next.js (3 minute read) React2Shell (CVE-2025-55182) is a critical unauthenticated remote code execution (RCE) vulnerability with a CVSS score of 10.0 in React Server Components (RSCs) that also impacts Next.js. title: Use Python for Scripting!
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-08, Reading time: 6 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fhypirion.com%2Fmusings%2Fuse-python-for-scripting%3Futm_source=tldrdevops/1/0100019afdeb0004-29db0d24-6ef5-486b-9d27-5dc19ce0de40-000000/0hI76ikykQONNrxfF5cmiK7lw9vd4AF4M_ncmugmlLQ=434
summary: Use Python for Scripting! (6 minute read) Python is a more portable, readable, and reliable choice than Bash for anything beyond simple scripting. It works consistently across systems and has a rich standard library. While Bash is fine for small tasks, Python avoids obscure syntax pitfalls and OS-specific behavior that often make shell scripts fragile and hard to maintain.

title: Migrating 6000 React tests using AI Agents and ASTs
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-08, Reading time: 7 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Feliocapella.com%2Fblog%2Fai-library-migration-guide%3Futm_source=tldrdev/1/0100019afdf05cd7-68050db4-377b-442f-8784-42bb6aaf3d25-000000/BQ8YYi3o4f45AZz14wCfsHtCr2zU_HKD6H4PMIt_Cug=434

Its team had Claude build a detailed migration guide first. They created an AST codemod to handle mechanical changes, then let Claude iteratively migrate 10 tests at a time while automatically running tests and checking coverage.

title: 21 Lessons from 14 Years at Google
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-08, Reading time: 15 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fopen.substack.com%2Fpub%2Faddyo%2Fp%2F21-lessons-from-14-years-at-google%3Futm_source=tldrdev/1/0100019afdf05cd7-68050db4-377b-442f-8784-42bb6aaf3d25-000000/m2IIyfyxCatULY1aYIYrxmKrilsmzaXqrKKhTQ2OzMQ=434
summary: 21 Lessons from 14 Years at Google (15 minute read) Great engineering is less about perfect code and more about understanding users, working well with people, and avoiding common traps. It's better to ship messy prototypes instead of debating perfect architectures forever, write clear code instead of clever code, and remember that your work doesn't speak for itself. People advocate for you in rooms you're not in.

title: Introducing Vercel for Platforms
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-08, Reading time: 1 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fvercel.com%2Fchangelog%2Fintroducing-vercel-for-platforms%3Futm_source=tldrdev/1/0100019afdf05cd7-68050db4-377b-442f-8784-42bb6aaf3d25-000000/mh1ulFMAwgx-sCpa3gDUrwsUEs7962uCqx8MsyWrlzE=434

summary: Apptron (GitHub Repo) Apptron is a local-first development platform. It creates a full Linux environment inside the browser with a VS Code-based editor that developers can do whatever they want with. Apptron can be used as a development environment and editor, a sandbox for AI and experiments, an editor to publish static sites, an embeddable software playground, or as a way to run and share Linux software on the web. It is fully extendable, customizable, and self-hosted.

title: I failed to recreate the 1996 Space Jam Website with Claude
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-08, Reading time: 15 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fj0nah.com%2Fi-failed-to-recreate-the-1996-space-jam-website-with-claude%3Futm_source=tldrdev/1/0100019afdf05cd7-68050db4-377b-442f-8784-42bb6aaf3d25-000000/nWyICCYkk6y4cJo76DTkxm3dnCiXoxFNI19Qm0hxkH8=434
summary: I failed to recreate the 1996 Space Jam Website with Claude (15 minute read) This dev tried to use Claude to precisely recreate the 1996 Space Jam website from a screenshot and assets, but found that it consistently failed to achieve pixel-perfect accuracy. Claude struggled with exact spatial positioning, admitting it couldn't measure pixel coordinates precisely. Claude's vision system likely processes images too coarsely to capture fine-grained spatial relationships.
